jsx.client
Class Win

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.client.Global
          jsx.client.Client
              jsx.client.Win

public final class Win
extends Client

A utility class accessing the functions of JavaScript with a full client-side support.

Users are encouraged to use the utilities provided in this class instead of the opaque methods of the JsGlobal, JsWindow or JsWin classes in consideration of the reuse benefit for re-compilation results.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org

Method Detail

alert

public static final void alert(java.lang.Object message)

Displays a simple message in a dialog box.

In JavaScript, this method displays the specified message to the user in a dialog box. The dialog box contains an OK button the user can click to dismiss it. The dialog box is typically modal, and the call to this function typically blocks until the dialog is dismissed.

Perhaps the most common use of this method is to display error messages when the user's input to some form element is invalid in some way. The alert dialog box can inform the user of the problem and explain what needs to be corrected to avoid the problem in the future

The appearance of the dialog box is platform-dependent, but it generally contains graphics that indicate an error, warning, or alert message of some kind. While it can display any desired message, the alert graphics of the dialog box mean that this method is not appropriate for simple informational messages like "Welcome to my blog"

Note that the message displayed in the dialog box is a string of plain text, not formatted HTML. You can use the newline character "\n" in your strings to break your message across multiple lines. You can also do some rudimentary formatting using spaces and can approximate horizontal rules with underscore characters, but the results depend greatly on the font used in the dialog box and thus are system-dependent.

Parameters:
message - The plain-text (not HTML) string to display in a dialog box popped up over the current window.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.alert(Object), Global.alert(Object), JsWindow.alert(Object)

confirm

public static final boolean confirm(java.lang.Object question)

Asks a yes-or-no question with a dialog box.

In JavaScript, this method displays the specified question in a dialog box. The dialog box contains OK and Cancel buttons that the user can use to answer the question. If the user clicks the OK button, it returns true. If the user clicks Cancel, it returns false.

The dialog box that is displayed by the this method is modal. That is, it blocks all user input to the main browser window until the user dismisses the dialog box by clicking on the OK or Cancel buttons. Since this method returns a value depending on the user's response to the dialog box, JavaScript execution pauses in the call to this method, and subsequent statements are not executed until the user responds to the dialog box.

There is no way to change the labels that appear in the buttons of the dialog box (to make them read Yes and No, for example). Therefore, you should take care to phrase your question or message so that OK and Cancel are suitable responses.

Parameters:
question - The plain-text (not HTML) string to be displayed in the dialog box. It should generally express a question you want the user to answer.
Returns:
true if the user clicks the OK button; false if the user clicks the Cancel button.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.confirm(Object), Global.confirm(Object), JsWindow.confirm(Object)

prompt

public static final java.lang.String prompt(java.lang.Object message)

Asks for simple string input with a dialog box.

This method displays text input field and OK and Cancel buttons in a dialog box. Platform-dependent graphics in the dialog box help indicate to the user that an input is desired.

If the user clicks the Cancel button, the method returns null. If the user clicks the OK button, it returns the text currently displayed in the input field.

The dialog box that is displayed by this method is modal. That is, it blocks all user input to the main browser window until the user dismisses the dialog box by clicking on the OK or Cancel buttons. Since this method returns a value depending on the user's response to the dialog box, JavaScript execution pauses in the call to this method, and subsequent statements are not executed until the user responds to the dialog box.

Parameters:
message - The plain-text (not HTML) string to be displayed in the dialog box. It should ask the user to enter the information you want.
Returns:
The string entered by the user, the empty string if the user did not enter a string, or null if the user clicked Cancel.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
prompt(Object, Object), Js.prompt(Object), Global.prompt(Object), JsWindow.prompt(Object)

prompt

public static final java.lang.String prompt(java.lang.Object message,
                                            java.lang.Object defaultInput)

Asks for simple string input with a dialog box.

This method displays the specified message in a dialog box that also contains a text input field and OK and Cancel buttons. Platform-dependent graphics in the dialog box help indicate to the user that an input is desired.

If the user clicks the Cancel button, the method returns null. If the user clicks the OK button, it returns the text currently displayed in the input field.

The dialog box that is displayed by this method is modal. That is, it blocks all user input to the main browser window until the user dismisses the dialog box by clicking on the OK or Cancel buttons. Since this method returns a value depending on the user's response to the dialog box, JavaScript execution pauses in the call to this method, and subsequent statements are not executed until the user responds to the dialog box.

Parameters:
message - The plain-text (not HTML) string to be displayed in the dialog box. It should ask the user to enter the information you want.
defaultInput - A string that is displayed as the default input in the dialog box. Pass the empty string ("") to make the method display an empty input box.
Returns:
The string entered by the user, the empty string if the user did not enter a string, or null if the user clicked Cancel.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
prompt(Object), Js.prompt(Object, Object), Global.prompt(Object, Object), JsWindow.prompt(Object, Object)

clearInterval

public static final void clearInterval(java.lang.Object intervalId)

Cancels periodic execution of code.

This method stops the repeated execution of code that was started by a call to setInterval(JsFunction, Object). intervalId must be the value that was returned by a call to setInterval(JsFunction, Object).

Parameters:
intervalId - The value returned by the corresponding call to setInterval(JsFunction, Object).
Since:
1.0
See Also:

clearTimeout

public static final void clearTimeout(java.lang.Object timeoutId)

Cancels a pending timeout operation.

This method cancels the execution of code that has been deferred with the setTimeout(JsFunction, Object) method. The timeoutId argument is a value returned by the call to setTimeout(JsFunction, Object) and identifies which deferred code to cancel.

Parameters:
timeoutId - A value returned by setTimeout(JsFunction, Object) that identifies the timeout to be canceled.
Since:
1.0
See Also:

setInterval

public static final java.lang.Object setInterval(JsFunction<?> f,
                                                 java.lang.Object interval)

Executes code at periodic intervals.

Note that the specified function is executed in the context of the Window object, that is, the Window object is the value of the this keyword of the executing context of the function. This is true even if the call to setTimeout(JsFunction, Object) occurred within a function with a longer scope chain.

Parameters:
f - A function to be periodically invoked.
interval - The interval, in milliseconds, between invocations of the function.
Returns:
A value that can be passed to clearInterval(Object) method to cancel the periodic execution of the function.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
clearInterval(Object), Js.setInterval(JsFunction, Number), Global.setInterval(JsFunction), Global.setInterval(JsFunction, Number), JsWindow.setInterval(JsFunction, Object), Interval

setTimeout

public static final java.lang.Object setTimeout(JsFunction<?> f,
                                                java.lang.Object delay)

Executes code after a specified amount of time elapses.

Note that this method executes the specified function only once. The function is executed in the context of the Window object, that is, the Window object is the value of the this keyword of the executing context of the function. This is true even if the call to setTimeout(JsFunction, Object) occurred within a function with a longer scope chain.

Parameters:
f - A function to be invoked after the delay has elapsed.
delay - The amount of time, in milliseconds, before the function should be executed.
Returns:
A value that can be passed to the clearTimeout(Object) method to cancel the execution of the function.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
clearTimeout(Object), Js.setTimeout(JsFunction, Number), Global.setTimeout(JsFunction), Global.setTimeout(JsFunction, Number), JsWindow.setTimeout(JsFunction, Object), Timeout

addEventListener

public static final void addEventListener(java.lang.String type,
                                          JsFunction<?> listener,
                                          java.lang.Boolean useCapture)

Adds an event handler function to the set of event handlers for the current JsWindow.window object. This is a DOM-standard method supported by all modern browsers except IE.

This method adds the specified event listener function to the set of listeners registered on this node to handle events of the specified type. If useCapture is true, the listener is registered as a capturing event listener. If useCapture is false, it is registered as a normal event listener.

This method may be called multiple times to register multiple event handlers for the same type of event on the same node. Note, however, that the DOM Specification makes no guarantees about the order in which multiple event handlers are invoked.

If the same event listener function is registered twice on the same node with the same type and useCapture arguments, the second registration is simply ignored. If a new event listener is registered on this node while an event is being handled at this node, the new event listener is not invoked for that event.

When a node is duplicated with JsNode.cloneNode(Boolean) or JsDocument.importNode(JsNode, Boolean), the event listeners registered for the original node are not copied.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsElement and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked.
listener - The event listener function that is invoked when an event of the specified type is dispatched to this node. When invoked, the listener function is passed an JsEvent object and is invoked as a method of the node on which it is registered.
useCapture - If true, the specified listener is to be invoked only during the capturing phase of event propagation. The more common value of false means that the listener is not invoked during the capturing phase but instead is invoked when this node is the actual event target or when the event bubbles up to this node from its original target.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
attachEvent(String, JsFunction), removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsWindow.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), Document.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsDocument.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean)

removeEventListener

public static final void removeEventListener(java.lang.String type,
                                             JsFunction<?> listener,
                                             java.lang.Boolean useCapture)

Removes an event handler function from the set of handlers for the current JsWindow.window object. This is a standard DOM method implemented by all modern browsers except IE.

This method removes the specified event listener function. The type and useCapture arguments must be the same as they are in the corresponding call to addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean). If no event listener is found that matches the specified arguments, this method does nothing.

Once an event listener function has been removed by this method, it will no longer be invoked for the specified type of event on this node. This is true even if the event listener is removed by another event listener registered for the same type of event on the same node.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsElement and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be deleted.
listener - The event listener function that is to be removed.
useCapture - true if a capturing event listener is to be removed; false if a normal event listener is to be removed.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
detachEvent(String, JsFunction), addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsWindow.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), Document.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsDocument.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean)

attachEvent

public static final void attachEvent(java.lang.String type,
                                     JsFunction<?> listener)

Adds an event handler function to the set of handlers for the current JsWindow.window object. This is the IE-specific alternative to addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean).

This method is an IE-specific event registration method. It serves the same purpose as the standard addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean) method, which IE does not support, but is different from that function in several important ways:

  • Since the IE event model does not support event capturing, this method and detachEvent(String, JsFunction) expect only two arguments: the event type and the handler function.
  • The event handler names passed to the IE methods should include the "on" prefix.
  • Functions registered with this method are invoked with no JsEvent object argument. Instead, they must read the JsWindow.event property of the JsWindow.window object.
  • Functions registered with this method are invoked as global functions, rather than as methods of the node on which the event occurred. That is, when an event handler registered with this method executes, the this keyword refers to the JsWindow.window object, not to the event's target node.
  • This method allows the same event handler function to be registered more than once. When an event of the specified type occurs, the registered function is invoked as many times as it is registered.

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsElement and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked, with a leading "on" prefix.
listener - The event listener function that is invoked when an event of the specified type is dispatched to this node. This function is not passed any arguments but can obtain the JsEvent object from the JsWindow.event property of the JsWindow object.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), detachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsWindow.attachEvent(String, JsFunction), Document.attachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsDocument.attachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsElement.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)

detachEvent

public static final void detachEvent(java.lang.String type,
                                     JsFunction<?> listener)

Removes an event handler function from the current JsWindow.window object. This is the IE-specific alternative to the standard removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean) method.

This method undoes the event handler function registration performed by the attachEvent(String, JsFunction) method. It is the IE-specific analog to the standard removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean). To remove an event handler function for a node, simply invoke this method with the same arguments you originally passed to attachEvent(String, JsFunction).

The same method is also defined by, and works analogously on, the JsElement and JsWindow objects

Parameters:
type - The type of event for which the event listener is to be invoked, with a leading "on" prefix.
listener - The event listener function that is to be removed.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
removeEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), attachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsWindow.detachEvent(String, JsFunction), Document.detachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsDocument.detachEvent(String, JsFunction), JsElement.detachEvent(String, JsFunction)

Decodes a string escaped with encodeURI(Object).

Parameters:

Returns:
A copy of s, with any hexadecimal escape sequences replaced with the characters they represent.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a URIError if one or more of the escape sequences in s is malformed and cannot be correctly decoded. See Js.err(Object) and JsURIError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
encodeURI(Object), Js.decodeURI(Object), Global.decodeURI(Object), JsGlobal.decodeURI(Object)

eval

public static final java.lang.Object eval(java.lang.Object s)

Evaluates the argument string as JavaScript code and returns the result.

In JavaScript, eval() is a global method that evaluates a string of JavaScript code in the current lexical scope. If the code contains an expression, eval evaluates the expression and returns its value. If the code contains a JavaScript statement or statements, it executes those statements and returns the value, if any, returned by the last statement. If the code does not return any value, eval() returns undefined. Finally, if code throws an exception, eval() passes that exception on to the caller.

The global function eval() provides a very powerful capability to the JavaScript language, but its use is infrequent in real-world programs. Obvious uses are to write programs that act as recursive JavaScript interpreters and to write programs that dynamically generate and evaluate JavaScript code.

Most JavaScript functions and methods that expect string arguments accept arguments of other types as well and simply convert those argument values to strings before proceeding. eval() does not behave like this. If the code argument is not a primitive string, it is simply returned unchanged. Be careful, therefore, that you do not inadvertently pass a String object to eval() when you intended to pass a primitive string value.

For purposes of implementation efficiency, the ECMAScript v3 standard places an unusual restriction on the use of eval(). An ECMAScript implementation is allowed to throw an EvalError exception if you attempt to overwrite the eval property or if you assign the eval() method to another property and attempt to invoke it through that property.

Parameters:
s - A string of JavaScript code.
Returns:
The return value of the evaluated code, if any.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a SyntaxError if the argument string does not contain legal JavaScript, a EvalError if the eval function was called illegally, through an identifier other than "eval", or other JavaScript error generated by the code passed. See Js.err(Object), JsSyntaxError, JsEvalError, and JsError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.eval(Object), Global.eval(Object), JsGlobal.eval(Object)

isFinite

public static final boolean isFinite(java.lang.Object v)

Tests whether a value is a finite number.

Parameters:
v - The number to be tested.
Returns:
true if v is (or can be converted to) a finite number, or false if v is NaN (not a number) or positive or negative infinity.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.isFinite(Object), Global.isFinite(Object), JsGlobal.isFinite(Object)

isNaN

public static final boolean isNaN(java.lang.Object v)

Tests whether a value is the not-a-number value.

In JavaScript, This function tests its argument to determine whether it is the value NaN, which represents an illegal number (such as the result of division by zero). This function is required because comparing a NaN with any value, including itself, always returns false, so it is not possible to test for NaN with the == or === operators.

A common use in JavaScript of this function is to test the results of parseFloat(Object) and parseInt(Object) to determine if they represent legal numbers. You can also use isNaN(Object) to check for arithmetic errors, such as division by zero

Parameters:
v - The value to be tested.
Returns:
true if v is (or can be converted to) the special not-a-number value; false if v is any other value.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.isNaN(Object), Global.isNaN(Object), JsGlobal.isNaN(Object)

parseFloat

public static final java.lang.Double parseFloat(java.lang.Object value)

Parses a number from a string.

In JavaScript, this function parses and returns the first number that occurs in value. Parsing stops, and the value is returned, when it encounters a character in value that is not a valid part of the number. If value does not begin with a number that it can parse, the function returns the not-a-number value NaN. Test for this return value with the isNaN(Object) function. If you want to parse only the integer portion of a number, use parseInt(Object) or parseInt(Object, Object) instead of this one.

Parameters:
value - The string to be parsed and converted to a number.
Returns:
The parsed number, or NaN if value does not begin with a valid number. In JavaScript 1.0, this function returns 0 instead of NaN when value cannot be parsed as a number.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
parseInt(Object), Js.parseFloat(Object), Global.parseFloat(Object), JsGlobal.parseFloat(Object)

parseInt

public static final java.lang.Integer parseInt(java.lang.Object value)

Parses an integer from a string.

In JavaScript, this function parses and returns the first number (with an optional leading minus sign) that occurs in value. Parsing stops, and the value is returned, when it encounters a character in value that is not a valid digit for the specified radix. If value does not begin with a number that it can parse, the function returns the not-a-number value NaN. Use the isNaN(Object) function to test for this return value.

Parameters:
value - The string to be parsed.
Returns:
The parsed number, or NaN if value does not begin with a valid integer. In JavaScript 1.0, this function returns 0 instead of NaN when it cannot parse value.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
parseFloat(Object), parseInt(Object, Object), Js.parseInt(Object), Global.parseInt(Object), JsGlobal.parseInt(Object)

parseInt

public static final java.lang.Integer parseInt(java.lang.Object value,
                                               java.lang.Object radix)

Parses an integer from a string in a base specified.

In JavaScript, this function parses and returns the first number (with an optional leading minus sign) that occurs in value. Parsing stops, and the value is returned, when it encounters a character in value that is not a valid digit for the specified radix. If value does not begin with a number that it can parse, the function returns the not-a-number value NaN. Use the isNaN(Object) function to test for this return value.

The radix argument specifies the base of the number to be parsed. Specifying 10 makes this function parse a decimal number. The value 8 specifies that an octal number (using digits 0 through 7) is to be parsed. The value 16 specifies a hexadecimal value, using digits 0 through 9 and letters A through F. radix can be any value between 2 and 36.

If radix is 0 or is undefined, this function tries to determine the radix of the number from value. If value begins (after an optional minus sign) with 0x, it parses the remainder of value as a hexadecimal number. If value begins with a 0, the ECMAScript v3 standard allows an implementation of this function to interpret the following characters as an octal number or as a decimal number. Otherwise, if value begins with a digit from 1 through 9, it parses it as a decimal number

Parameters:
value - The string to be parsed.
radix - An optional integer argument that represents the radix (or base) of the number to be parsed. If this argument is undefined or is 0, the number is parsed in base 10 or in base 16 if it begins with 0x or 0X. If this argument is less than 2 or greater than 36, NaN is returned.
Returns:
The parsed number, or NaN if value does not begin with a valid integer. In JavaScript 1.0, this function returns 0 instead of NaN when it cannot parse value.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
parseInt(Object), Js.parseInt(Object, int), Global.parseInt(Object, int), JsGlobal.parseInt(Object, Object)
